key_title: Key to the species of Drosera

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Droseraceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Conn, B.J. (1996). Droseraceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Stem present; leaves cauline (sometimes a basal rosette also present)
Stem reduced, hence leaves in a basal rosette
Leaves linear, not peltate
Leaves hemispherical, more or less peltate
Stem scrambling or climbing, weak; leaves regular, circular in outline, peltate
Stem more or less erect, self-supporting; leaves irregular, more or less lunate, subpeltate
Sepals glabrous; basal rosette usually absent; seeds cylindrical, >0.8 mm long
Sepals hairy; basal rosette usually present; seeds variable in shape, rarely cylindrical,  <0.8 mm long
Stem leaves 1–5 mm diam.; seeds ovoid or obovoid with surface shallowly elongate-reticulate; stems usually thread-like, unbranched or branching from base
Stem leaves 4–10 mm diam.; seeds fusiform, often curved, with surface deeply pitted; stem short and robust, unbranched or branching towards apex or at base
Leaf-lamina once or twice divided into narrow-linear lobes
Leaf-lamina entire, not linear
Stipules present
Stipules absent or fused to base of lamina and so appearing absent
Stipules more or less entire, fused to base of petiole, 1–2 (–2.5) mm long
Stipules variously divided
Stipules 3-partite distally, 3–5 mm long; sepals, petals and stamens each 4
Stipules laciniate, 5–7 mm long; sepals, petals and stamens each 5
Leaves sheathing at base; lamina linear to narrowly oblong; petiole slightly narrower than lamina
Leaves not sheathing at base; lamina spathulate to obovate, gradually tapering into an indistinct petiole
Petals orange or red, 4–5 mm long; tuber absent
Petals white, rarely pink, 8–12 mm long; tuber present
